chapter.title: How to use OBS web UI
chapter.para: This chapter explains and shows how you could use OBS web UI. We will show and use OBS web UI based on . You need to make an account first to follow this chapter contents.

section.title: Start page and Login
section.para: Open your favorite browser and navigate to
To proceed, you'll need to log in and authenticate with your username and your password. Click on Login and enter the data in the upper right corner.
After successful authentication, you'll end up on the start page again - with new options visible. We'll go through most of them in detail, but first lets create your home: in the next step.

section.title: Home project
section.para: Every user has a home project (home:[userid]) where he/she has write access by default. This is your personal workspace where you can experiment and play. Click on the link "Home Project" at the upper right to get to your home project.

section.title: The project page
section.para: Your home project will be empty for now, but you can add packages containing sources/build recipes and projects which are containers for the build targets. As you can see, you're the default maintainer which grants you full write access to this project. You're also the bug owner of your project.

section.title: Changing a project's title and description
section.para: On every project page you will find a "Edit description" link. This link will lead you to a place were you can review and change your project's title and description. Click on the "Update project" button to save.

section.title: Creating subprojects to a project
section.para: Subprojects are projects that are part of another projects namespace. Subprojects are an easy way to organize multiple projects. On the "Subprojects" tab you can find a list subprojects that belong to a project. To create a new subproject click on the "New subproject" link, fill in the form and press the "Create project" button.

note.para: Please note that maintainer of upper projects always can modify the sub projects. Apart from that all projects are seperated and have no influence to each other.

section.title: My Projects, Server Status
section.para: Let's leave for now your home: for a bit and explore the build service. Click on "My Projects" on the left at the bottom. This opens a page listing your watched projects and your involvements in projects or packages.

Now, let's visit the main monitor page by clicking on "Status Monitor". You see here the status of the services, some graphs and graphics are showing the currently running and completed jobs an the overall load.

section.title: Create a link to a package in your home:
section.para: We'll show you how you can log in and use the web interface hosted at build.opensuse.org. This includes login, adding a link to a package in your personal workspace (home:) and how to build that package by adding a repository. First, let's enter "My Projects" by clicking on the link at the bottom left.

Now let's create a link to a package and add a repository to build against. A link is basically a pointer to sources of an already existing package. By "repository" we mean container of built binary packages like Debian_8 or openSUSE_13.2. Let's follow these steps:
Add link to the existing package.
Add repository.
Observe the build on the monitor page.
Look at package's page.

section.title: Repository Output: Built Packages
section.para: To find the RPMs you built, go to your home project page and click Repositories. From there click on the blue repository name. For example, openSUSE_Factory:

note.para: Published repositories are marked with the OBS LKW

section.para: Now click on Go to download repository. Note that publishing the repository might take a while. Until then you will get a 404 error. Once the binaries are there, you'll see something like this:
Your rpms can be found in the subdirectories, and the .repo file is suitable for use with zypper, yum or other repository-friendly package management tools.

section.title: Managing Repositories
section.para: This section will show how you can manage your project's repositories.

section.title: Adding a repository
section.para: To add a repository to your project, click on "Add Repositories" on the project's repository tab. This will direct you to a list of possible distributions you can built packages for, see .

note.para: If you could not find a repository that fits your needs, you might want to switch to the expert mode. Click on the "Expert mode" link right to the button. This page allows you to search and select a repository of any project available in OBS and add it to your projects repository list.

section.para: This will take you back to your home: project. The build repository might be disabled: if so, klick on the cogwheel to enable it. Congratulations, it is configured. On a heavily loaded server, it can sometimes take a few minutes for your changes to become effective, but your linked package will automatically begin building.

section.title: Add Download on Demand repositories to a project
section.para: When you have administrator rights you will be able to add Download on Demand repositories to your project. To do so, click on the "Add DoD repository" link and enter your DoD repository data into the form.

The minimal set of fields you have to enter are architecture, repository type and the url that provides the binary packages. Detailed information about the data you can enter here you can find at the DoD concept section. Press "Save" to create the repository.
Once the repository got added you are able to edit, delete or add additional DoD repository sources.

section.title: Edit DoD repository sources
section.para: To edit DoD repository sources after they got added click on the "Edit" link that you find right to each DoD repository source.
